items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

1. Position Management
	 
a. Job Description Revision
	 
Revision to the Police Sergeant job description.  See attached job description.
	 
b. Position Elimination
	 
Elimination of Executive Secretary, 100% FTE, (9ADMS0202N) in the Administrative Services Department at the District Office effective 08/26/14.
	 
c. Position Establishment
	 
Establishment of Confidential Executive Administrative Assistant, 100% FTE, (9ADMS0204N) in the Administrative Services Department at the District Office effective 08/27/14.  See attached job description.
	 
2. Change of Status
	 
a. Promotion
	 
The employee is promoted to Business Services Supervisor, 100% FTE, (9IBCD0217S) at the Workforce Institute from College Fiscal Coordinator, 100% FTE, (8BUSS0212C) in the Administrative Services Department at Evergreen Valley College effective 09/01/14.
	 
b. Lateral Transfer
	 
The employee is laterally transferring to Executive Administrative Assistant to the President, 100% FTE, (8PRES0202N) in the President's Office at Evergreen Valley College from Confidential Executive Administrative Assistant, 100% FTE,  (9ADMS0204N) in the Administrative Services Department at the District Office effective 09/15/14.

items.item_details:
The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.
	 
Short-Term Position Establishment  
The establishment of the following position at Evergreen Valley College effective 08/18/14 and 09/02/14: 
Mentor Support 
Translation and Interpretation (T & I) Tutor

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $84,100 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.

items.item_details:
This Amendment 01 to the Agreement with the District is entered into for the purpose of extending the Agreement from July 1, 2014 through June 30, 2015 and otherwise amend the Agreement as stated herein.
	 
Therefore, it is mutually agreed between the parties that the Agreement is amended as follows:
	 
Section 2 "Duties of District as Grantee" subsection 2.01a is hereby added as follows, effective as of July 1, 2014:
	 
2.  DUTIES OF DISTRICT AS GRANTEE
	 
District shall:
	 
2.01a  Complete the tasks and requirements in Participating College's Core Roles and Responsibilities and Campus Work Plan 2014-2015 Program Year, Exhibit A, attached hereto and incorporated by reference.
	 
Section 3 "Terms of Grant" subsection 3.01 is hereby amended as follows, effective as of July 1, 2014:
	 
3.  TERMS OF GRANT
	 
3.01  The term of this Agreement shall be for a period of two (2) program years; beginning July 1, 2013 and through June, 30, 2015.  All performance under this Agreement shall be completed by June 30, 2015.  In order to receive complete reimbursement under this Agreement, District shall ensure that Foundation for California Community Colleges (FCCC) has received Year End Report and Final Monthly Reimbursement Invoice no later than July 15, 2014 for the 2013-14 fiscal year, and no later than July 15, 2015 for the 2014-15 fiscal year.  These documents shall be addressed to the Director:
	 
Youth Empowerment Strategies for Success -ILP
Foundation for California Community Colleges
1102 Q Street, Suite 3500
Sacramento, CA  95811
Attn:  Colleen Ammerman
	 
Section 4 "Grant Amounts and Payments" subsections 4.01a, 4.04c, and 4.05 are hereby amended as follows, effective as of July 1, 2014:
	 
4. GRANT AMOUNT AND PAYMENTS
	 
4.01a  In consideration of satisfactory performance of services described in this Agreement and Exhibits, FCCC agrees to pay the District a total amount not to exceed $22,500, as set forth in 2014-2015 YESS-ILP Budget, Exhibit B, attached hereto and incorporated by reference.
	 
4.04.1 Payments shall be made as set forth below:
	 
c.  Funds available under this Agreement that are not expended within the corresponding performance period (July 1, 2013 - June 30, 2014 and July 1, 2014 - June 30, 2015) and invoiced by District within the corresponding invoicing guidelines (July 15, 2014 and July 15, 2015) shall revert back to FCCC.
	 
4.05  District is required to provide FCCC a forecast of the current year's annual expenditures by December 1, 2013 and December 1, 2014.
	 
Section 5 "Agreement Revisions and Level of YESS-ILP Student Enrollment" subsections 5.01 and 5.02 are hereby amended as follows, effective as of July 1, 2014:
	 
5. AGREEMENT REVISIONS AND LEVEL OF YESS-ILP STUDENT ENROLLMENT
	 
5.01  Changes to this Agreement, District's performance objectives, work plan, budget, and student enrollment levels must receive prior written approval by Director.
	 
5.02  District's Evergreen Valley College is required to enroll and serve fifty (50) youth in Life Skill Training classes and/or activities.
	 
Section 6 "Reports" subsection 6.03 is hereby amended as follows, effective as of July 1, 2014:
	 
6. REPORTS
	 
6.03  Final Monthly Reimbursement Invoice and Year End Report:  Submitted to FCCC no later than July 15, 2014 and July 15, 2015, using prescribed forms.
	 
Section 15 "Non-Discrimination and Affirmative Action" is hereby replaced with the following, effective as of July 1, 2014:
	 
15.  NON-DISCRIMINATION AND AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
	 
15.01  During the performance of this Agreement, District, participating colleges within the district, and any of its subcontractors shall not unlawfully discriminate, harass, or allow harassment against any employee or applicant for employment because of sex, race, color, ancestry, religious creed, national origin, physical disability (including HIV and AIDS), mental disability, medical condition (e.g. cancer), age (over 40), marital status, and denial of family care leave.  District shall insure that the evaluation and treatment of their employees and subcontractors shall comply with the provisions of the Fair Employment and Housing Act (Gov. Code ยง 12990 (a-f) et seq.) and the applicable regulations promulgated thereunder (California Code of Regulations, Title 2, ยง 7285 et seq.).  The applicable regulations of the Fair Employment and Housing Commission implementing Government Code Section 12990 (a-f), set forth in Chapter 5 of Division 4 of Title 2 of the California Code of Regulations, are incorporated into this Agreement by reference and made a part hereof as if set forth in full.  District shall give written notice of their obligations under this clause to labor organizations with which they have a collective bargaining or other Agreement.  District shall include the nondiscrimination and compliance provisions of this clause in all subcontracts to perform work under this Agreement.
	 
15.02  District shall comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of disability, as well as all applicable regulations and guidelines issued pursuant to the ADA. (42 U.S.C. 12101 et seq.)
	 
All other terms of said agreement shall remain unchanged and in full force and effect.

items.item_details:
Per California Public Contract Code Section 20652, "the governing board of any community college district without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be in the best interest of the district, may authorize by contract, lease requisition, or purchase order ... [to] purchase materials, supplies, equipment ... and other personal property for the district in the manner in which the public corporation or agency is authorizes by law to make the lease or purchase." The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of a negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation agency.
	 
On March 9, 2010 (Board Item F-10), the Board of Trustees authorized the award of a contract without advertising for bids by determining that its was in the best interest of the District to 'piggyback' on the contract between the Western States Contracting Alliance (WSCA)/National Association of State Procurement Officials (NASPO) and Dell Marketing, LLP as the single source supplier of the District technology equipment. This agreement enabled the District to obtain the highest value for every dollar spent on technology equipment through August 31, 2014.
	 
On July 9, 2014, WSCA/NASPO Contract Administration approved Master Price Agreement B27160 Amendment Number 3, to extend the expiration date to December 31, 2014. Therefore, when considering the best interest of the District, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees approved the extension of a piggybackable contract between WSCA/NASPO and Dell Marketing, LLP without the need to further advertise for bids on an already competitively bid contract. 
	 
Attached are an affidavit of publication, an approval of award recommendation dated April 10, 2009 and the WSCA/NASPO Master Price Agreement B27160 Amendment Number 3.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to extend a 'piggyback' on a contract with Dell Marketing, LLC.
items.item_text: Extension of Piggyback Dell Marketing, LLP Contract
items.item_text_raw: 11. Extension of Piggyback Dell Marketing, LLP Contract

items.item_details:
By contracting with the State Chancellor's Office, the District may recover outstanding student debts owed such as enrollment fees and library fines.  Under the program, the State Chancellor's Office requests the Franchise Tax Board to offset (deduct) the amount owed to the District from the student's personal State income tax refund, lottery winnings, or other State refund.  The Franchise Tax Board remits any amounts offset to the State Chancellor's Office, who then authorizes the State Controller's Office to disburse the offset amount, less a 25% administrative fee, to the District.
	 
The program is one of a multi-pronged approach to recover outstanding student debts.  The District sends emails to students throughout the term advising of their outstanding balance and providing options to satisfy their outstanding balance (e.g., payment plan, financial aid, etc.).  Upon completion of the term, students who still have an outstanding balance despite receiving emails during the term are sent a letter advising that the balance remains outstanding, that a hold is on their account, the options available to them to satisfy their outstanding balance, and that failure to satisfy the outstanding debt may result in their account being referred to an external collection agency.
	 
Last year, the District referred $2,155,683 in outstanding student debt and recovered $262,121 through the 2014 Chancellor's Office Tax Offset Program (COTOP).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the contract with the State Chancellor's Office for the District to participate in the 2015 Chancellor's Office Tax Offset Program (COTOP).
items.item_text: Approval of Agreement with the State Chancellor's Office for the 2015 State Chancellor's Office Tax Offset Program (COTOP)
items.item_text_raw: 12. Approval of Agreement with the State Chancellor's Office for the 2015 State Chancellor's Office Tax Offset Program (COTOP)

items.item_details: The State has reinstated to the community college system Schedule Maintenance Funds beginning in Fiscal Year 13-14.   The District received $172,087 in Fiscal Year 13-14.  In Fiscal Year 14-15, the District anticipates receiving $1.6 million to be allocated between Scheduled Maintenance Funds and Educational Equipment.  80% of the Fiscal Year 14-15 State allocation has been directed to the Colleges, 20% has been allocated to the District.  The Fiscal Year 13-14 allocation and a portion of the 20% District allocation for Fiscal Year 14-15 will be used to protect the investment in the new District Office building at 40 S. Market by assuring that the  building exterior walls are water tight.   This contract is for the necessary work to replace the existing exterior caulking system around all granite panels and to replace portions of the exterior sheet  metal.  This Scheduled Maintenance work will be performed concurrent with the completion of the interior remodel, by the same contractor, which provides cost and schedule efficiencies, but does not impact the G2010 bond project budget for the New District Office. This scope of work was originally included in the RFP, but not awarded pending verification of funds available.  Now that Scheduled Maintenance funds have been allocated by the State, the work described in this ICA can proceed.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve an Independent Contractor Agreement with XL Construction in the amount of $375,107 to furnish and install complete Exterior Deferred Maintenance Work for the New District Office Building.
items.item_text: State Schedule Maintenance Funding: San Jose Evergreen Community College District - New District Office Renovation #G2010.0060, Project #39301 XL Construction Exterior Deferred Maintenance Work for the New District Office Building, Independent Contractor Agreement
items.item_text_raw: 13. State Schedule Maintenance Funding: San Jose Evergreen Community College District - New District Office Renovation #G2010.0060, Project #39301 XL Construction Exterior Deferred Maintenance Work for the New District Office Building, Independent Contractor Agreement

items.item_details:
The City of San Jose (work2future) included Workforce Institute in its 2014 WIA Overall Cohort Training Pool Contract and awarded a NTE contract pool of $ 2,091,797 to each of its service providers (the contract was board approved on May 13, 2014.)  Funds were allocated as needed to select providers to provide cohort based educational instruction to WIA eligible clients looking for a career change or to upgrade their skills to increase employability. The original contract term covered 3/1/14 through 6/30/14 and included workshops for Job Readiness and Job/Entrepreneurial training for the Allies grant and other Staff Development workshops. 
	 
The City of San Jose is amending the above referenced 2014 WIA Overall Cohort Training Pool Contract: modifying the term to 3/1/14 through 6/30/15 and increasing the pool amount by $1,574,858 for a total 2014-15 workshop pool contract amount of $3,666,625.  Workforce Institute anticipates realizing $230,000 in 2014-15 from this Training Contract Pool.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the First Amendment to 2014 WIA Overall Cohort Training Pool Contract
items.item_text: First Amendment to 2014 WIA Overall Cohort Training Pool Contract
items.item_text_raw: 14. First Amendment to 2014 WIA Overall Cohort Training Pool Contract

items.item_details:
California Public Contract Code Section 20651 requires the District to advertise publicly for bids for the purchase of goods or services involving an expenditure which exceeds the state-mandated bid limit. However, if sufficient evidence is provided to support a finding by the Board of Trustees that a competitive bidding process is not feasible or practical, and that sole source procurement is in the best interest of the District, then an exception may be allowed under these circumstances.
	 
The District Research and Institutional Effectiveness office uses IBM SPSS and IBM SPSS Modeler for analysis of enrollment data, survey research, and other data analysis related to student success and other initiatives.  RIE has established SPSS as the software of choice for research and analysis.  With an increase in the number of research analysts providing service to the colleges and the district, there was a need to increase the number of concurrent licenses available.  This increase has put the contract for SPSS Modeler over the allowable threshold as per Section 20651.
               
Because IBM is the sole manufacturer of SPSS and owns all rights to any source code, patents, copyrights, and distribution rights, it is not possible to purchase these needed analysis products from anyone except this one vendor.  One of the strengths of IBM SPSS and IBM SPSS Modeler is in its ability to integrate data mining and analysis into one application.  This means that the analyst can import data from various sources, including data warehouses, extract needed fields and variables into datasets, and analyze these datasets using commonly known SPSS analysis tools.  This has proven invaluable for RIE in creating information such as resides in the Fact Books, Fast Facts, and Balanced Scorecard for the district. 
	 
The District has obtained a sole source letter from IBM identifying themselves as the only distributor of the SPSS products with sole rights to licensing, maintenance, and support.  This letter along with the quote for the concurrent licenses and support.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve IBM as a sole source provider for IBM SPSS Modeler software and related products and support services for use in data mining and analysis.
items.item_text: Sole Source Procurement of IBM SPSS Modeler Software
items.item_text_raw: 15. Sole Source Procurement of IBM SPSS Modeler Software

items.item_details:
On May 14, 2013 the Board of Trustees approved the utilization of the Design-Build delivery method for the Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center.  
The District issued a Request for Proposal (RFP) to prequalified Design/Build Entities and received proposals from three firms. The selection committee consisted of representatives from San Jose’ Evergreen Community College District and Milpitas Unified School District. The respondents’ proposals were reviewed against the requirements set forth in the RFP and ranked according to a point value system assigned to each of four categories. The committee selected McCarthy Building Companies, Inc. / Steinberg Architects for this project, who achieved the highest ranking of 82.92 points, representing the best overall scores awarded for Price, Technical Expertise, Management Plan and Interviews.
	 
The Contract Value is $7,500,000
	 
New Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center
Design/Build Entity Selection:
	 
	 
COMPOSITE SCORES
Turner /
					MVEI
McCarthy/
					Steinberg
Swenson/
					HMC
AVERAGE SCORE
71.10
82.92
70.70

items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the agreement with McCarthy Building Companies, Inc. / Steinberg Architects to be the Design/Build team of the new Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Education Center.

items.item_details:
On October 8, 2013 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with XL Construction, to provide design-build services for the renovation of the new District office located at 40 S. Market Street. Construction contracts often times experience unforeseen conditions, coordination gaps and/or design changes, particularly renovations and Design-Build contracts that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  During the Design phase and initial inspection of the building items were reevaluated for long and near term value to the District.  This process precipitated design changes and subsequent change requests from XL Construction.  These change requests were reviewed for accuracy and conformance with the contract documents.
	 
Original Contract Amount               $ 6,100,000
Previous Approved Changes          $    771,579

items.item_details:
﻿﻿﻿﻿Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) - SALAS O’BRIEN ENGINEERS –PAA #SJCC-04 Utility Extension for New and Existing Buildings Design Services Phase 2
Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) - SALAS O’BRIEN ENGINEERS –PAA #SJCC-04 Utility Extension for New and Existing Buildings Phase 2 Design Services.
	 
In conjunction with Project #31110 Utility Extension for New and Existing Buildings Phase 2, SALAS O’BRIEN ENGINEERS worked with SJCC and the Program Manager to provide Programming and Assessment services to determine College needs and priorities for extending and modernizing the campus utility infrastructure.  In order to reduce spending on temporary measures the Utility Extension for New and Existing Buildings project was then adjusted into two separate phases, “Phase 1” and “Phase 2”.  Work related to Phase 01 focused on relocating utilities and making provisions for the first of two future buildings scheduled to be constructed in the current location of building 300.  Phase 01 work is now complete. 
	 
Work related to Phase 2 will consist of providing infrastructure that will support the addition of the new gymnasium as well as continuing the construction of infrastructure to support the future facilities.
	 
Due to their expertise knowledge and experience with the existing campus infrastructure and work performed through Phase 01 Design Services and Construction Phase administration associated with Phase 2 was negotiated with Salas O’Brien. 
	 
The Board is asked to approve PAA SJCC-04 to SALAS O’BRIEN ENGINEERS in the amount of $169,500 for Designer/Engineer of Record Services for Project #31110 Utility Extension for New and Existing Buildings Phase 2.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve PAA SJCC-04 to SALAS O’BRIEN ENGINEERS in the amount of $169,500 for Designer/Engineer of Record Services for Project #31110 Utility Extension for New and Existing Buildings Phase 2.

On March 11, 2014 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Kitchell CEM Inc. to provide construction services to upgrade buildings 100 and 200 at San Jose City College. These upgrades included the construction of new ADA compliant restroom facilities, new power, telecommunications, heating and cooling, repairs to the roof system and modernization of the classrooms spaces. 
	 
Construction contracts often times experience unforeseen conditions, coordination gaps and/or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  This Change Order No. 002 adds a new electrical panel and other miscellaneous electrical work, insulation and fire barrier in classroom ceiling spaces and other necessary repairs to these buildings.

items.item_details:
In July of 2012, the Board of Trustees approved a Lease-Leaseback project delivery method for the South Campus Development (SCD) project at Evergreen Valley College (EVC).  Blach Construction Company was awarded a Pre-construction Services Agreement on February 12, 2013 with a Board Agenda stating a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) and Site & Facilities Lease Agreements would be brought back to the Board for approval.
	 
With the completion of the pre-construction services this month, Blach Construction is ready for the next step in the Lease-Leaseback delivery method - to begin the construction of the South Campus Development project.  The budgeted construction value of the project is $42,841,187 including contingencies.
	 
At the completion of construction documents in December, 2013 the project was submitted to Division of the State Architect (DSA) for review and approval.  During that time the architect, HMC, and Blach provided reconciled project estimates of $40,500,000 for the work.  DSA approved the project in late July, 2014. At that time Blach put the project out for subcontractor bidding and assembled the GMP.  However, a combination of market factors including increases for materials and high local construction demand have affected pricing.  Preparatory to the final GMP a significant effort was provided by college and District staff, Gilbane, HMC and its consultants and Blach to achieve the lowest project costs.  As a result of these efforts Blach has presented a GMP of $41,639,729.  While the overall project budget will support the value of this contract, efforts will continue through the course of construction to identify cost-savings measures to the project.  Please note that while this is a âguaranteedâ maximum price, the GMP is subject to adjustments for extra work and changes as directed by the District.  
	 
Upon execution of the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease, Blach will be granted access to and control of the site to commence construction.  Completion of the construction will be achieved within 562 calendar days from the issuance of the Notice to Proceed.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees execute the Site Lease and Facilities Lease Agreements for the construction of the South Campus Development Project, at Evergreen Valley College to Blach Construction, Inc. with a Guaranteed Maximum Price in the amount of $41,639,729.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC South Campus Development Site Lease and Facilities Lease Agreements to Lease-Leaseback
items.item_text_raw: 10. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC South Campus Development Site Lease and Facilities Lease Agreements to Lease-Leaseback

items.item_details:
On December 10, 2013 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Galeb Paving, Inc. to provide construction services for parking lots & street maintenances project at Evergreen Valley College Campus.  The scope of work included the first phase of a northern loop road to connect the east and west EVC parking lots and provide pavement marking for curbs of parking lots 1, 1A, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8 and select portions of Paseo de Arboles Road. 
	 
Galeb Paving’s contract required them to stockpile of soil in anticipation of needs at other EVC projects.  That need did not materialize so Galeb is now asked to remove the stockpile.   Change Order No. 003 is a discretionary change by EVC and the District for relocation of the approximately 8,000 cubic yards of excess soil from the EVC stockpile to District property.  The soil is being moved to prevent runoff from entering the surrounding parking lots and adjacent storm drain system.  The newly relocated soil will also be hydro-seeded to prevent wind-blown dust dispersal and buildup of weedy material.  A Ninety (90) Calendar day no-cost schedule extension for additional work associated with soil relocation and hydro-seeding is also included in this Change Order.  The contract substantial completion date is being extended Ninety (90) calendar days from June 2, 2014, to August 31, 2014.
	 
Galeb Paving Inc. submitted written pricing proposals for changes detailed in the Agenda attachment that include additional or deleted materials, equipment, labor, time extensions as applicable and the prescribed mark-ups.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
The two items in this change order result in an ADD to the contract of $59,851.00.
	 
Original Contract Amount            $ 756,000.00
Previous Approved Changes       $   11,967.00 (course-of-construction changes)
Change Order #003                     $   59,851.00 (discretionary change for stockpile relocation)
Total Contract and Changes        $ 827,818.00
	 
The total of Change Orders 1 and 2 to Galeb’s contract (work that was the result of design and field conditions) is $11,967.00, which equates to 1.58% of the base contract.  The total of all changes (Change Orders 1, 2 and 3) is $71,818 and equates to 9.5% of the base contract.
	 
The Substantial Completion Date is changed to August 31, 2014.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 003 for Galeb Paving, Inc. in amount of $59,851.00 for the Parking Lots & Street Maintenance Project at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
Cluster Roble is identified to be demolished as part of the 2025 Facility Master Plan for Evergreen Valley College.  The Main Distribution Frame (MDF) room, which houses the primary transfer equipment for telecommunications systems at EVC, is located in Roble and must be relocated.  An Architect of Record (AOR) is required for the design and life safety requirements review of building systems such as mechanical and electrical requirements for a new proposed location of the MDF in the Administration / Student Services building.
                                                                                                                              
On July 8th, 2014 the campus IT staff (CTSS) and Gilbane met with Dougherty + Dougherty Architects to discuss the relocation of the MDF.  Dougherty + Dougherty was selected to submit a proposal for these services as an extension to their design services currently being completed within the same building as the new MDF location.  The proposal presented by Dougherty + Dougherty for the not-to-exceed amount  of$145,500 will include programming of the space requirements, design, construction documents and bidding and construction administration services necessary to complete the project.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the issuance of a Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) No. EVC-02 to Dougherty + Dougherty Architects, LLP in the not-to-exceed amount of $145,500, to provide architectural services for the Main Distribution Frame (MDF) relocation at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College (EVC) MDF Relocation Project - Dougherty + Dougherty Project Assignment Amendment No. EVC-02
items.item_text_raw: 12. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College (EVC) MDF Relocation Project - Dougherty + Dougherty Project Assignment Amendment No. EVC-02

items.item_details:
The Infrastructure Upgrade Project (#39705) was created on November 12, 2013, when the Board of Trustees approved the split of the ERP Conversion Project (#39704 - $10,000,000) into two equal parts of $5,000,000 each for the ERP Conversion Project and the Infrastructure Upgrade Project.  The scope of the Infrastructure Upgrade Project is to provide a âfault tolerant network and server environment to serve both Colleges and Workforce Institute from the District Office Data Center.â  The first phase of the project will be the build-out of the 40 S. Market Data Center and associated Network, followed closely by projects at SJCC and EVC.
	 
On May 30, 2014, the District issued an RFP (RFP #G2010.0099 SJECCD IT Broker Integrator Infrastructure Services Partner) for broker/integrator services for discovery, design, planning and supplying the required hardware and implementation services to complete the build-out of the new data center and network design.  The RFP served to qualify vendors with significant manufacturer relationships and certifications, as well as identify local resources available to assist the District in long-term efforts to complete this significant infrastructure upgrade effort. Two proposals were submitted by the extended due date of June 18, 2014 and It was unanimous among the evaluation committee members that Dasher Technologies provided the best solutions for the District. The evaluation committee consisted of representatives from the District Office, EVC and SJCC -- CampusWorks CIO, VP of Administrative Services, Interim VP of Administrative Services, Network Technology Manager, Supervisor of CTSS, Senior Systems Administrator, Lead Applications Analyst and two Purchasing Agents. On July 8, Board Item G.13 was presented to the Board. Due to a vendor protest during public comment, the Board authorized proceeding only with three projects (SJCC Building 100/200, the new District Office and the EVC Campus Police Building) in order to maintain the critical schedules for said projects until further review. The RFP process was reviewed by CampusWorks CIO, Assistant Director of Fiscal Services and the District CISO and the District was satisfied that it followed the RFP process. The District responded and met with the vendor that voiced their protest and now considers this matter resolved. 
	 
This Master Agreement is based on a Master Agreement Template for professional design services and will serve as a basis for requesting future Project Authorization Amendments (PAAs) for IT infrastructure discovery, planning and design services.
	 
In addition, the District will develop Independent Contractor Agreements (ICA) for purchasing and installation services. These will be presented to the Board for approval at a future meeting.
	 
Dasher Technologies is a small, local, women owned business and has partnered with another small, local business for Data Center design and relocation.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve a Master Agreement with Dasher Technologies for Information Technology Systems and Infrastructure Design Services based on RFP # G2010.0099, SJECCD IT Broker Integrator Infrastructure Services.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: RFP # G2010.0099 SJECCD IT Broker Integrator Infrastructure Services Partner Master Agreement
items.item_text_raw: 13. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: RFP # G2010.0099 SJECCD IT Broker Integrator Infrastructure Services Partner Master Agreement

items.item_details: Pending approval of a Master Agreement with Dasher Technologies for Information Technology Systems and Infrastructure Design Services, this Project Amendment Authorization request (PAA #DIST001) is for Dasher Technology to provide network migration discovery and design services to determine all dependencies required to implement and support the new proposed network architecture for the new District Office network at 40 S. Market St. This service will enable Dasher to develop a Project Plan for the final network installation and migration from the existing District Office to the new District Office.
items.item_recommendation: Approve Project Amendment Authorization # DIST001 with Dasher Technlogy for providing Network Migration Discovery and Design Services for the new District Office at 40 S. Market St. based on the Master Agreement.

items.item_details:
This item was presented to the Board of Trustees on July 8, 2014 as an information item.  The Evaluation Committee is recommending through the Chancellor that the Board of Trustees award a five-year contract to Follett Higher Education Group to operate the two campus stores.
	 
The contract agreement is attached for reference.  Highlights include:
	 
Follett will provide the community with a full range of affordable course materials, new textbooks, used textbooks, digital textbooks, custom published materials, rental textbooks, general books, reference books, supplies, computer/technology supplies, general merchandise, emblematic clothing, gifts, greeting cards, convenience items, health and beauty aids, special order services, graduation related merchandise, class rings, and other services expected from a full-service campus store.
Follett will manage and operate a full-service website/online order program.
Follett will attend the Campus Stores Advisory Committee with the goal of developing and improving campus store programs, services, and policies.
Follett will provide employment opportunities to students.
Follett will provide a monthly commission payment based upon sales.
Follett will invest $50,000 in the form of a facilities investment.
Follett will invest $52,000 for the installation of a point-of-sale and store management system.
Follett will provide $10,000 annually for scholarships.
Follett will provide discounts to all departments, faculty, and staff.
At the campuses' request, Follett representatives will participate in the upcoming Professional Development Days to provide information to the campus communities and to respond to any questions or concerns.  
	 
Follett's response to the District's Request for Proposal is attached for reference and representatives from Follett Higher Education Group and Campus Bookstore Consulting are present to respond to any inquiries.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award a five-year contract to Follett Higher Education Group for operation of the campus stores.

items.item_details:
The scope of this project entails renovating one office, while adding another office to the boiler room.  The offices will house maintenance staff.  These offices are necessary due to the demolition of the staff’s existing offices in Building 300.  The final amount includes the base bid and bid alternates #1 and #4. Alternates #1 and #4 will add a window to one office and carpet to both offices, respectively.  
	 
A public bidding process for contractors was conducted between July 23, 2014 and August 11, 2014.  The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website, advertised in local papers on July 23, 2014, July 28, 2014 and published at 20 local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 100 contractors.  Bids were opened at 3 pm on August 11, 2014.  Only one bid  was received.  Based on the evaluation of the bid price and required documentation, it was determined that R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. should be awarded this contract.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of a construction contract to R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. in the amount of $112,326 for the San Jose City College Repurpose Boiler Plant Phase II: Boiler Room Office Addition Project.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Government Code Section 3547, the California School Employees Association, Chapter 363 presents their Reopener Proposal with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District for 2014-2015.  The California School Employees Association, Chapter 363 will provide the Articles to be negotiated for 2014-2015, during the board meeting.
	 
	 
CSEA respectfully submits the following bargaining proposals:
	 
Article 6: Salary
CSEA has an interest in a fair and equitable pay increase.
CSEA has an interest in modifying the Campus Police retirement system from CalPERS to CalPERS Safety.
CSEA has an interest to modify Police Officer shift rotation to address the need of shift selection by seniority.
CSEA has an interest to increase the salary for Temporary or Permanent reassignment of a Unit Position with Higher Salary Range.
	 
Article 8:  Work Schedule
CSEA has an interest to add language that would allow for an alternate work schedule during the summer months.
	 
Article 21:  Retirement Benefits
CSEA has an interest in a permanent “Bridge Plan” for eligible CSEA bargaining unit members.
	 
Article 23:  Reclassification
CSEA has an interest in adding an appeal process.
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Present CSEA’s contract reopener proposal for 2014-2015, and announcement of a public hearing to be conducted at the September 9, 2014 Board meeting.

items.item_details:
The Measure G-2010 New District Office Renovation project is approximately 3/4 complete.  The following update summarizes recent accomplishments and upcoming activities.  
Construction progress - Major recent accomplishments include: completion of the new roof and installation of new rooftop HVAC equipment.  The first floor tenant, Univision, was moved to their new location on the 5th floor, which allows for the first floor Board Room work to commence.  All construction work will be completed by early October.   
Other contracts  - Separate bid packages are being developed for new furniture, relocation of existing furniture and building contents, audio/visual equipment, security systems and IT cabling.  Each of these  bids will result in separate contracts presented for Board approval at the September 9 and October 14 meetings.  Installation of furniture and equipment will take place throughout the months of November and December.
Existing furniture - More than 50% of the furniture from the existing District Office will be relocated to the new building.  Each piece of furniture was evaluated by District staff and an independent consultant for suitability for use in the building. The evaluation criteria included structural soundness, ergonomic standards, functionality in the new location and color/style compatibility.  Savings to the District from re-using furniture is in the range of $200,000 to $250,000.   
Parking â This has been a high priority since the decision was made to move District operations downtown.  We have explored many options, including City parking garages, with distance from the new building and operating costs as important considerations.  Our current plan is to purchase monthly parking passes, for District employees, Trustees, campus leaders and constituency group leaders, at a private garage located at 60 S. Market, right across Post Street from the new office.  We plan to provide payment vouchers to invited guests and to the public for Board meetings.   Our objective is to make parking as affordable, convenient and safe as possible, for all participants in the work of the District. 
Moving - We are tentatively scheduling the physical move to 40 S. Market for the holiday break.  The actual move date will depend upon the actual completion of significant building systems such as data, audio visual and security.  We are monitoring these bid packages closely to assure a timely and successful relocation process. 
Budget - A budget and expense forecast report is enclosed with this information item.
